sub_topic: Show that every group of order 10 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C10, the dihedral group D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10.
message_1: Find all distinct groups of order 10 up to isomorphism and state which of the three possible isomorphic groups (C10, D5, or the non-abelian group of order 10) each one is isomorphic to.
message_2:
To find all distinct groups of order 10 up to isomorphism, we can use the following facts:

1. The order of a group is the product of the orders of its Sylow subgroups.
2. The number of Sylow p-subgroups is congruent to 1 mod p and divides the order of the group.

Since 10 = 2 * 5, there are two Sylow subgroups: a Sylow 2-subgroup of order 2 and a Sylow 5-subgroup of order 5.

By the second Sylow theorem, the number of Sylow 2-subgroups must divide 5 and be congruent to 1 mod 2. The only possibility is that there is one Sylow 2-subgroup. Similarly, the number of Sylow 5-subgroups must divide 2 and be congruent to 1 mod 5. The only possibility is that there is one Sylow 5-subgroup.

Since there is only one Sylow 2-subgroup and one Sylow 5-subgroup, they are both normal. Let P be the Sylow 2-subgroup and Q be the Sylow 5-subgroup. Then the group G can be written as the internal direct product of P and Q, i.e., G = P x Q.

Now, we have two cases:

1. P is cyclic of order 2 and Q is cyclic of order 5. In this case, G is the direct product of two cyclic groups, and G is isomorphic to the cyclic group of order 10, C10.

2. P is the Klein four-group of order 2 and Q is the cyclic group of order 5. In this case, G is the direct product of the Klein four-group and a cyclic group, and G is isomorphic to the dihedral group of order 10, D5.

However, since the order of P is 2, it cannot be the Klein four-group, so the second case is not possible.

Therefore, there is only one distinct group of order 10 up to isomorphism, and it is isomorphic to the cyclic group of order 10, C10.
